reviewText:
Summary:
Even in this time of indie games reviving game genres of old, the Pang genre hasn't exactly gotten a plethora of games. The Bug Butcher however does the genre proud, with its twitch gameplay doing its best to bring out the strengths of the genre. Great visuals complement action that forces you to keep shooting and killing, but being smart about it and not being reckless. While the game could use a little bit more variety for the long haul, what's there is extremely polished. Great performance plus loading times that are practically non-existent help in getting you right back in the action and keeping you there. It's a genre that gets to the basics, and The Bug Butcher is no exception to that. But small smart decisions regarding the gameplay helps make a game that kept me entertained throughout me playing it, and well worth the price point in question. Definitely a worthy successor in the genre, updated for the new age.

Video Review: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0-8_5-Suh28

Lists:
+:
Tight twitch gameplay that keeps the action going. Takes me back to the old arcade days.
Solid controls that give you the right amount of control, and can allow you to be reckless and deal damage to yourself. That may sound weird to say, but part of the appeal of these games is the twitch gameplay, and consequences.
Strong aesthetic that complements gameplay. Great use of color choice to make action clear for the player.
Great performance, and minimal load times. How an arcade game should play.
Like the gravity mechanics with enemies and hitting them with your gun. It increases the skill ceiling especially with the combo multiplier.
Honestly, the game is probably under priced, even at it's full price. Feel like for the experience, you get your money's worth and then some.
-:
Do wish there was a little bit more variety in the long run. A couple more weapons, levels, and enemy types would have done wonders.
Feel like the upgrade system doesn't really do much other then add a bulletpoint feature to the game. Very basic.
I really can't put my finger on it, but something feels missing with the sound design. I didn't see a real difference in gameplay when turning the sound off, which is unusual for games like this. But I can't say WHAT is missing.

Early Access Review

The Bug Butcher starts off as a tribute to 1989 bubble-dividing arcade game Pang, but quickly mutates into a turbo-charged, explosive twitch blaster.

On the surface it's simple - run horizontally, shoot vertically and blast everything before the time runs down. Shoot a large alien and it divides into two medium ones, shoot THEM and they divide again into two small ones. If you fail to mop up the smaller aliens, you become overwhelmed.

But as the game throws more types of alien at you, it becomes a game of tactics and timing. Can you dash under those five bouncing aliens to get to that crucial power-up? When do you set off the kill-everything homing missiles? Which alien is the priority kill?

Gameplay video:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=z_sJdW4x58I

Soon enough the aliens require your every reaction to deal with. There's a roof-crawling ant thing that blasts down a vertical pole of lightning for several seconds at a time. There's a leaping facehugger that means instant death. And one plant-like thing slowly sucks up your NPC friend in the background and, if you don't kill the plant in time it'll fail you the level. And so on.

The cartoon art is excellent and funny. The alien pests are full of bug-eyed charm, explosions feel satisfying and your hero Harry gets all the best lines.

The levels are scored in a very Angry Birds three-star system. You can progress just for completing the level, but getting just one star does hurt and you'll want to try again. The key to high scores is keeping a chain of kills (ie combos) going without being hurt. Some levels you'll unlock new weapons and power-ups.

Every coin you collect on a completed level earns you coins that you can spend on permanently upgrading your character (weapon power, power-up strength, speed boost etc). Flipside, there's less incentive to keep plugging away for three-star ratings early on when you know your character can be much stronger after a few more levels.

The levels are split into groups of six, each group taking place in one location in the research facility. Six feels like a lot - by the fifth, it feels a bit this room AGAIN?!". But then the final level suddenly throws you into a confined elevator level

reviewText:
The Bug Butcher is an action indie game with both singleplayer and co-op gameplay.
If this review is too long for you, I suggest you to only read the first paragraph about the game's content and the final verdict at the end.

What is happening in the game:If you're similar with Pang or maybe Bubble Trouble, this is exactly the same type of game. You have to shoot the enemies that are bouncing around the room and the only direction you can shoot at is upwards. You play as The Butcher, who specialises in killing monsters in this exact same situation.

Pros:    Gameplay | It's always nice to see when somebody makes a remake of an old classic game, but these remakes are usually just counting on player's nostalgia, instead of making a genuinely good game. Fortunately, this is not the case in The Bug Butcher. The gameplay is smooth and works as well as it should. It doesn't change the principle it's based on, but enhances it.
Graphics | This game has a really nice colourful appearance that really makes this game stand out. I mean, just look at the Store page screenshots! All the effects look really nice, although they can get for a slight bit too confusing at times.
Weapons | There are different weapons in this game and you can also get a lot of upgrades and pickups that boost your performance, for example faster shooting. Variety plays a really important role in this remake.
Co-op | You can of course also play with your buddy, if you're having him in your home. There is also controller support, so you don't have to be cramped on the same keyboard.
Pricing | For such a nice game, I don't think $8 is a lot. It has hours and hours of gameplay, Steam Achievements and Leaderboards.
Stages | There are 30 story-based stages in different environments and there are also survival mission for both singleplayer and co-op modes. This is great if you want more fun after you completed the story missions.
Cons:    Controller Chaos | So, this game sometimes doesn't really let me play with my keyboard. The controls in game are always appearing as controller buttons, but in the options menu, everything is shown as keyboard buttons. This can be sometimes very confusing.
Learning Curve | Although this game is very easy to understand, it becomes too hard a little to quickly. But that is just my opinion.
The final verdict:This game is a really nice remake of old classic called Pang and it's really well-made. The graphics are awesome, there is even some story included. The confusion with controller/keyboard controls are the biggest problem in this game I see.
For its price, I think this game is definitely worth checking out as it offers quite a lot of fun.

Greetings,
BirdCute

Note that my copy of this game was obtained for free for reviewing purposes. However, this did not affect the quality and objectivity of this review.

reviewText:
Early Access Review

In The Bug Butcher you take on a role of Harry, a intergalactical mercenary bug exterminator who has been given a task on planet Zoit to deal with an bug infestation in a research compound. You must clear the research lab of bugs in order to keep the scientists working there safe.

Graphic design and visuals could be defined as grose and cute at the same time. All enemies you encounter are unique in terms of how they look and what they do, wrapped up in a cartoonish colorful look.

Before long you are freezing, bursting, frying and lasering hordes of strange-looking alien bug-beasts, and it feels so damn satisfying. Gameplay evolves around a static and unchanging environment where enemies dodge, crawl, fly, smash, bounce and even give birth to smaller versions of themselves.

As you progress through the levels you will acquire more powerful weapons, upgrades and power-ups. You will also collect coins from bugs you slaughtered in order to upgrade your stats and equipment.

Soundtrack is absolutely amazing and I wouldn’t be surprised if one day we get a soundtrack edition of the game.

The Bug Butcher is a fine example of a old-school style of gameplay with a lot of fun-factor involved. Although it lacks some verticality The Bug Butcher will make you spend hours on end progressing through the well designed and easy to look at lab slaughtering relentless hords of interesting and unique bug-like aliens.

reviewText:
I want to start this review off by letting everyone know that I am by no means a professional reviewer, i'm just someone who really loves games, and I like to play indie gems from time to time.

Alright so going into this games I kept my expectations in check due to being burnt by other games in the past, but I figured for $8 why not? But to my great pleasure this game is FANTASTIC.

Graphically the game looks handrawn reminds me of games like Critter Crunch with the 2D art work, the bugs splatter, the blaster/power up effects look good, and the bugs themselves look really good for what it all is.

Gameplay wise it's fairly simple but challenging, the bugs bounce up and down across the screen and you're character runs across the same screen only allowed to vertically (up), now on paper this sounds fairly boring and standard, but when you consider other elements like; creatures breaking into smaller variations of themselves, some creatures shooting little beams that could hurt you, stage hazards and more, it adds variety and challenge to the gameplay all while you're trying to keep a combo meter and your high score rising in order to reach individual goals in each level.

It seems pretty simple but as i went on and was pushed to increase my combos and score I found myself becoming more agile and offensive in my appoarch against these bugs, as opposed to waiting for them to bounce and go on killing them, more often than not i would rush them before they even hit the ground once.

The audio in the solid as expected, the musical score isn't anything too blaring or annoying, and usually i'm too focused on keeping my combos up to really care about the music.

Finally the replayablity in this game is actually quite excellent, mroe often than not I found myself repeating levels to hit each of the goals with in the levels, and even switching to a harder mode to challenge myself...I failed to mention this earlier but I actually enjoy how the harder mode mixes up the enemy spawns as opposed to just being the same as the lower modes with more enemies.

All in all, I love this game, the moment I played the demo, closed it out, and kept coming back to it over and over again, I knew I had to buy it, I reccomend that you do the same :)

reviewText:
Early Access Review

It's really hard to recommend this game. There are external problems and minor annoyances (menu isn't that user friendly with a controller) that would prevent me from recommending this game. However looking past these problems and only considering the quality of the game itself (in particular the graphics and the gameplay), I can do nothing else than recommend this game.

It's a very beautiful game, it runs smooth and the animations are great. I haven't had any performance isssues and it runs at a smooth 60 fps. The core gameplay is very solid. It's a vertical shooter where you have to defeat wave of increasingly harder (and different) enemies. It's easy to get in a great flow and there is enough of a challenge to keep you entertained.

So why is it really hard to recommend this game? The developers say the game has 30 levels (although only 18 are available in Early Access) and though it's technically accurate, it isn't really true. The real levels are called floors, of which there are only five. This results in very repetitive environments. The things the developer calls levels is just increasing the number of enemies (or adding another type) after a series of waves (four or five waves per level). This means there is a severe lack in content. In Early Access this is even worse.

A lack of content doesn't have to be a bad thing (if the quality is good, which is the case), but the game has to be priced accordingly. This however isn't the case. The price of the game is way too high. The developer even says they plan to increase the price of the game after Early Access. This would be a grave mistake. Even with the planned features it simply isn't worth € 9,99, not even by a long shot. This is a game that shouldn't be priced above € 4,99. I wouldn't even consider buying the game at € 9,99. If by mistake I did buy it, I would have asked for a refund based on the lack of content. I don't think I'm alone in this and the developers should really consider this. It would be a real shame this game would fail, because the developer didn't understand the value of the game. It shouldn't fail based on quality, but it will fail if the price isn't lowered.

TLDR:

- Should you buy the game in Early Access: No
- Should you buy the game for € 9,99: No
- Is the game worth playing: Yes
- Should you buy the game if has a lower price (€4,99 or below): Yes

FULL DISCLOSURE: I have recieved this game for free from the developer.

The bug butcher is a wave based fast paced shoot ‘em ‘up

You are a bug butcher who's trying to clear out a base.

Along you you got yourself a scientist which only you really need to save from spiders or else game over, Plus he will drop crates for you which have weapons like the laser beam, Rocket launcher, and two more.
There's a dash which is quite important you can spam it if you like but you won't be invincible if you use it.
And then you also have special abilities like freezing, invincibility and more (shot)speed.
The patterns of the enemies are quite simple either they bounce, shoot or just fly around they will be quite easy to learn.
At some point they also introduce walls and platforms they can get quite annoying especially in the last chapter.
And that is the main gameplay now unto the modes and such things.
You have three modes Campaign ( 30 levels ) which i found to be quite easy.
Then there's panic which is just a random wave mode which after a wave you can buy upgrades, and it's probably the place with most replayability next to the achievements.
There's also co-op which is just panic mode but with co-op  If you have any irl friends  But it's local only.
In the campaign you also have upgrades they are pretty basic weapon upgrades and abilities upgrades, but you also have these suit modifications like a shield i didn't really use them cause i didn't see the need for them
The campaign is pretty short it took me like 1.6 hours ( Note i lost my save at some point for buggy reasons so that's why i have more than 4 hours atm)
The difficulty however it doesn't change much it only changes the amount of health you have, like in hard you only have 1 health which is insta death on hit.

Character designs are nice aswell.
The ui however is awkward with a controller.
The sounds and music are all good but it's quite jarring to me when you die the music resets.
The other sounds are solid as well not much to say about them really

I did run into one bug which wiped my save which sucked.


So overall it's a good shoot em up with a good variety of enemies and a good soundtrack.
But with a short campaign but you'll probably spending most time in panic mode.
It comes with it flaw however the ui is just awkward.

Introduction:The Bug Butcher is an Indie Arcade shoot ‘em up developed and published by Awfully Nice Studios .

The core mechanics hold old ties from the classic arcade shooter “Super Pang” where you shoot vertically, but with modern day twists. You are Harry, a brash and tenacious exterminator who has a knack for decimating bugs.

What I noticed at a first glance:The controls are very tight and are simple enough for new players and complex enough for those who wish to go more in depth.
It’s a 2D, side scrolling game with a twist: instead of shooting across the screen at enemies, you shoot vertically.
Unforgiving difficulty that punishes you when you mess up. Not unfair; if you die, it was most certainly your fault.
The power-ups. There is a great variety of these, ranging from increased damage, attack speed, and freezing enemies. There are also weapons that can spawn in crates, each with its own advantages.
Tons of available upgrades to increase different stats and perks.
Impressive soundtrack and sound design in general. Electronic, sci-fi music mixed with the pew pew pew of your laser gun.
There are 3 game modes. Arcade missions act as a campaign mode with 30 levels. There is a set amount of time/waves of enemies that spawn. Panic (singleplayer) is a sungleplayer survival mode and Panic (co-op) is survival with local co-op enabled.
Enemies varies depending on level. Each has their own attack patterns, which easy to learn, making them somewhat predictable (and killable)
Cartoony, light-hearted art style that makes pest control in space seem more appealing then you ever thought it could be.
Levels are confined to a small space. I would enjoy a more open, free game mode where exploration was mixed with alien pest control. This may just be me, but I really enjoy games with certain aspects of freedom that allow the player to create his/her own unique experience.
Replay value to get achievements and beat your old scores.
SummaryI was impressed with the quality of this game. The controls are tight and the difficulty is unforgiving. If you have any interest in arcade shooters or games with big guns and lasers, I would highly recommend you at least check out the demo.

Charming? Check. Addictive? Check. Funny? Check. Soundtrack? Checkmate. The Bug Butcher in a nutshell? Amazing.

The Bug Butcher is a action shooter from Awfully Nice Studios. Currently, in Early Access on Steam for $7.99 (on sale from it's launch price of $9.99). Just having finished my first look of the game I have to say It's been awesome.

You see I've been following The Bug Butcher since around February when I found it had been Greenlit through Steam. While following on Facebook I was able to see this game developed over the last several months and with each animated enemy gif they posted I would get more and more interested. The art style alone is enough to want to give it a shot.

https://youtu.be/FDTSpLUNP64?t=16m50s

On the surface it seems that The Bug Butcher is a stylized shoot 'em up. Where the enemies are a series of very well designed bug alien creature thingies (I imagine this whole thing takes place way in the future on the bug planet Klendathu but that's my fantasy). Your ultimate goal is to splatter their gooey insides all over this space station and save the day.
You are fighting against the clock, leveling power ups, leveling perks, and frantically building your power up meter to beat the round. Trust me you'll need the power ups in the harder difficulties as you only have 1 health. As you finish each level you are awarded stars based on your final score, there are a possible 4 stars per level. You are also given coins, these coins are used to purchase upgrades to the aforementioned perks and power ups. The power ups are random and unlock at certain levels, the two I came across were rapid fire and freeze grenades.

For an early access game The Bug Butcher is polished very well. All the animation, sound production, and gameplay is tight and well done. I didn't come across anything that stood out as broken". It gets an A+ there. Having followed the development over the last few months I'm excited for the rest of the content

Feature        Y/N/Rating                Aspect Ratios        Menu UI messy beyond 4:3-16:9, still playable                Triple Monitor        Possible                Framerate Cap        144+                Performance        Just Fine                Options        Almost None (Audio Vol/Toggles)                Key Rebinding        Yes, Incomplete                Controller Support/Rebinding        Yes, No                Local Co-op        Endless Co-op Mode
PC Port Quality
The HUD while playing is fine, but all of the menus have an abundance of issues. They look slick, but elements break apart and hidden elements are shown when scaled wider than 16:9. The menus support keyboard/mouse/controller, but it seems like a mashup of shortcuts that work well on some and not on others. It’s really quite a mess beyond the first glance, and while none of this effects the gameplay, it does cause resetting the level to be a pain depending on your input method. A Keyboard-only level reset takes 13 inputs... There's plenty of room for a reset key; it would alleviate a ton of the frustration during the more difficult stages.

Key rebinding is present but isn’t complete, and controller is limited to one default mapping which I don’t find to be all that optimal. I opted for the keyboard for all of my play at the end of the game, as the default mapping played well, and was the most responsive considering the movement is digital rather than analog. Local Co-op is playable with a a single keyboard and/or controllers. Co-op keyboard defaults make little sense, but can be rebound separately from the singleplayer controls.

The game supports at least 144hz and forces v-sync. However, the camera and walking enemies update position matching the refresh, while the bouncing enemies update around 60hz and will appear to stutter.

Gameplay
The core gameplay across all modes entails walking along the floor, dashing, and firing directly upwards, as bugs crawl out of every surface. It's similar to a traditional arcade shooter (Galaga / Space Invaders) but the dash and variety of enemy movements/attacks make it quite unique. Each bug is color-coded, contrasting strongly with the background environments. This is key as their movement, attack, and self-replication patterns are consistent; reading them becomes essential when trying to perfect a level. None of the bugs actively seek you out in any way; you position yourself to avoid collisions and line up attacks. You can use your dash to put yourself in the way of danger to kill faster; you’re rewarded for that risk. Dashing won’t trigger while holding the fire button, so you can’t be sloppy with your inputs.

The main single-player mode consists of 30 levels across 5 areas, each with score targets for 1-3 star ratings and a target combo, achieved by killing bugs in succession before the 4 (6 w/ perk) second timer ticks down and without getting hit. The difficulty options simply adjust your maximum health, allowing you to take 1, 4, or 8 hits before death. You can survive through the 30 levels pretty quickly without too much trouble, but he challenge is meeting the score and combo-count requirements for each stage. While the difficulty setting has no impact on score, taking all of those hits and losing your combo each time will likely see you falling short of those goals. Losing the combo once in the middle of the stage could cut your final score by more than half, and leave your maximum combo under the target, as it’s usually seems tailored to 50-80% of the spawned bugs.

All of the bug spawns are orchestrated; you can memorize the patterns and will likely need to when perfecting the final few levels. I believe power-ups and weapons are dropped from specific enemies, but the actual item you get is randomized. There are coins to collect, and while they add slowly to your score, their intended use is buying upgrades to the weapons and power-ups, as well as 3 perks. Again, because of the score-attack focus, I don’t see why there is any progression system at all, though you’ll have the money for every unlock before you finish a single run through. It becomes irrelevant before you go back to complete all the score and combo targets. A better use for the coins in my mind would have been costumes for the player character; still something to unlock and look forward to, without putting you at an immediate disadvantage.

Panic, the only other mode at the moment, is an endless score attack and is playable with one or two players locally on the 5 maps. Players can revive each-other by spamming the A button over their body during a small window after they’re downed. The coins here are accumulated during the run, are reset upon death, and can be spent in the pause menu to enable all of the power-ups and passive buffs from the singleplayer. A deploy-able bubble shield is also added to the roster of power-ups. There are no achievements or unlocks tied to this mode, but kills during do contribute to the achievements, and it was good fun with a friend. A local VS mode was shown off a while back, but doesn’t exist in the current build.

Overall it's very tight and satisfying, but there will be certain moments where you feel cheated. I came across instances of glitches and inconsistencies that forced a reset. It’s all somewhat excusable, until it happens in the run you were nailing, ruining it and and frustrating the experience. Questionable choices involving components in the levels that can redirect enemies unexpectedly, bug out and block shots, or even kill you directly. Certain power-ups can also cause certain bugs to spaz out in unpredictable ways. It’s largely a fair and rewarding challenge, but when those conflicts can get to you. It's minor and only really appears in the end-game, but still something to be worked on.

Presentation
A mix of Jetpack Joyride, Castle Crashers, and Awesomenauts, the visual aesthetic is exceptional. There’s a small amount of aliasing on some of the assets, but it’s largely crisp and defined, with excellent color choice. The bug designs, while nothing iconic, all have a goofy charm and wear bright colors that both assist in gameplay and look great. In hectic scenes, you’ll have many colors going at once, yet it remains unified because of the contrasting but not clashing color choices. The core sound effects are well defined, but the thumping electronic music was hit or miss for me.

Conclusion
The Bug Butcher is a satisfying and unique 2D arcade shooter, where speed and precision are heavily rewarded. It’s charming, vibrant 2.5D cartoon aesthetic is very appealing but also helps keep hectic situations readable. While relatively light on content, it’s score attack format and achievements had me enjoying myself all the way to 100% completion in around 8 hours of play, with only a small amount of frustration perfecting the final few levels, stemming from small glitches or inconsistencies. The menu UI needs some work and though the port is nowhere near top-notch, it’s good enough to be enjoyable on ultra-wide and high refreshrate displays. Co-op functionality for the 30 main missions, additional modes in general, and small enhancements like visual character customization would be greatly appreciated if development continues. In it’s current form it’s a good value and is well worth a look.

reviewText:
At first you're like, Pang? then you're like, Shoot 'em up? then you're like... Ohh yeah, it's bug Butcher time!

If you're a fan of shoot'em ups of games like electronic super joy, you're probably going to really enjoy this. There is a lot of action on the screen at times and while to the extent of something like Ikaruga, it does provide a welcome alternative to the space ship shooters without the need of a platform jumper.

However, those looking for a class Pang remake may be a little disappointed at first, but surprisingly pleased by the out come. It gives a nice, faster, more up beat game play as well as a few new weapons to play with giving a refreshed feel, if you don't mind the missing ropes.

Gameplay wise, there isn't really much in the way of upgrades for the character. I think I managed to max out everything I could in the first few hours. The game has a nice tutorial to get you into the swing of things and you'll soon be awarded with new weapons to use and upgrade.
As you progress you've presented with new bugs to kill, each with their own abilities and things you need to watch out for and different means of dealing with them. Some rooms have different envo hazards you need to watch out for, or use to your own advantage.

I've like to see Steam workshop support added, a basic level editor for community levels to make things interesting. Right now there is the fixed path of the single player mode, that once beat on hard (it is btw) you'll only be able to get higher scores againt world and friends. The alternatives are co op and the endless mode where you kill bugs for extra time pickups. You play until time runs out or you die. The Co-op is nice and is well suited for TV gameplay.

As it stands, it's well worth the asking price.

reviewText: The Bug Butcher is a fast pased shooter that seems halfway in between a vetical scrolling bullet hell game and a platformer type one. Each level is a fairly small contained area, and like most vertical scrollers, most enemies come in from the top, and you can only shoot up, however the enemies stick around until they are defeated and there is a floor which many can bounce around on, and some stop and rest on. Player movement is constrained to just left and right on the floor. The lack of a jump in this perspective seems like a bit of a strange choice, especially since it would come in useful on occasion for evading incoming attacks when there's another enemy sitting next to you. Some enemies are capable of firing projectiles, some just a few at a time, but others do 10s at a time in patterns, although the enemies bouncing around the floor are usually the primary threat to your health. The game is usually quite hectic keeping a fairly quick pace with a large amount of enemies at most times. The player can dashsideways to help dodge, which recharges very quickly. It took a while for me to get used to dashing, as buttons to slow your movement tend to be more common in vertical shooting games than speeding up, and you must stop shooting to dash, so you can't just hold shoot forever. I was a bit hesitant about whether I wanted to try this at first, as trying to run under jumping enemies in most platformers tends to be a source of frustration and difficulty, however I didn't have an issue with it here. Enemies jump high enough and are floaty enough that you have plenty of  time to manuver below them, and most slow their decent when hit, giving you more time when attacking. Once I got the hang of this, I was able to play much more aggressivly than I originally thought would be possible, dashing underneath falling enemies and shooting, and if necessary dashing back out before they hit the ground. This may actually be required, as you may get overrun otherwise, and this game is quite difficult. Different arenas have different gimmicks to them, and there is a large variety of enemy types, each of which attacks and moves differently, so the game stays fairly fresh despite it's simple mechanics. The player handles well, and the collision works as it should, I never felt as if I was screwed by oversized hitboxes. The soundtrack is great and fits well with the theme of the game. Unfortunatly the coop is local only, and therefore worthless to me, however there's still plenty of single player content to do.

Review :The Bug Butcher is a really fun shooter.

Gameplay :You play as a bug killer of some sort to kill some special alien bugs that have invaded the facility and you have to kill them all.
There is a catch though. You have a time limit for each stage, from 2-3 minutes and if you haven't killed the aliens before the timer
runs out you lose.
There are also scientists that if killed you lose. Only Spiders can kill them though.
There are a powerup that can freeze the timer and enemies, called a Freeze Grenade.

You have a Machine gun as standard weapon, but you can find pickup weapons on the ground that randomly spawns.
You also have powerups you can use after you have charged your powerup meter by killing the bugs.

You can run from side to side and dash.
You only shoot vertical upwards.

Sometimes tactics are a good thing to have, like if you have a Freeze Grenade or Homing Missiles,
use it while there are tons of enemies on the screen or if you need to buy more time.

There are 30 stages split up in 5 maps. Each time you change map you are in an elevator and you face enemies on your way up.
There are new enemies in the elevator so you have some knowledge about what you can face in the next map.

There are lots of different types of bugs like; small fireball bugs, Huge bugs that splits to smaller bugs when killed,
some kills you in one hit if the land on your head, ect.
The game is so much fun, the controls are smooth and the music fits so well to the game.

I think there is a tiny bug, when you choose any of the game modes that it shows the controller buttons on the upgrade menu, insted of keyboard keys

The game would fit as a Mobile/Tablet game too due to the simple gameplay and controls.

Game Modes: Arcade is the story mode of the game, with 30 stages split into 5 maps.
Panic is Survival. Survive 3 mins or until death in one of 5 maps.
Panic Co-op is Co-op Survival. Same rules, Survive 3 mins or until death in one of 5 maps.
There are shops after wave 1 and every two rounds afterwards.

Weapons: Machine Gun is your standard weapon.
Laser Beam is a beam that kills the bugs with one hit.
Rocket Launcher shoots spread fire missiles.
Gatling Gun is a fast shooting gun.
Lightning Gun deals chain damage to bugs near the bug hit by the shot.

Powerups: Speed Injection boosts your attack speed for a limited time depending on level of upgrade.
Freeze Grenade Freezes Both Bugs and the timer for a limit time depending on level of upgrade.
Homing Missiles shoots Homing Missiles at the bugs and the amount of missiles depends on level of upgrade.

Perks: Speed Booster makes you move 30% faster.
Bug Shield gives you a shield protected against 1 hit and doesn't break combo on hit.
Combo Booster makes the combo last 6 seconds insted of 4 seconds.

Pickups: Double Damage are fire shots that deals double damage.
Bullet Storm makes you shoot twice as fast.
Heart give you 1 health
Time Watch gives you more time (Only in Panic)

Early Access Review

I held off recommending this game until the addition of local co-op Panic Mode was released.
On its own, single player mode is solid and provides some chaotic moments but overall it lacks the polish and replay value that other contenders in the same arena can offer (ahem, Assault Android Cactus).

However the cooperative local player is where this title truly shines and reveals some of the most frenetic fights for survival you can find. You'll battle nerves, frustration and bloodshot eyes as the luxury of blinking goes out the window.

The inability to map custom buttons is a real drawback and the menus (all of them) are atrocities to convention and miserable to navigate. Thankfully you won't spend too much time in them, and overall it's not exactly  a deal breaker since they're most likely working on bigger problems atm.


+ 6.5/10
+ Grab a friend to truly unleash the games potential.
+ Good Xbox 360 controller support.
+ Decent powerups provide enough variety with which to dispatch the vermin.
+ Well designed enemy mechanics.

- Lack of button mapping is a drawback (put that dash button on RT guys!)
- 2-player panic mode has a UI flaw that lets the player restart the game without a confirmation.
***You don't know how badly this needs to be fixed asap. Better to map the option to one of the start buttons all together.***
-The main title screen is drab and could potentially lower expectations from players from the get-go as an unfinished and cheap title.

Fix these flaws and spice up the level design/art and you've easily got an 8/10 game on your hands.

This is a positive review - but one thing should be made clear: this game doesn't have much in common with Super Pang (AKA Buster Brothers).

Super Pang is a precise platforming game where you methodically wore down bubbles while being careful and picking your moments.  You tapped the fire key with a deliberate rhythym to hit just the thing you wanted, and because you normally could only have one shot on the screen you were defenseless for a while if you wasted a shot.  You don't play Bug Butcher that way; you play Bug Butcher with the fire button held down, you shoot everything you can until there's nothing left, and you do it fast and loose and sometimes you take some damage (in Super Pang, you died in a single hit, which really changes the feel).  Both games have bouncing things, but deep-down they're very different games.

But anyway, yeah, Bug Butcher is a good action shooter; sometimes it feels like sort of a bullet hell platformer" maybe?  Great music

But if you do like it, you'll spend many hours trying to achieve that one combo score or trying to get higher in the world ranking. There's a bug (pun intended) in the localization, and some placeholder texts are still there. But these are minor flaws: it's about hectic gameplay, not about story. Nice start for this new indie team!

The Bug Butcher is a nice surprise to find on Steam. For $8, you are getting a LOT of action. I want to say its about 30 levels and the game has special challenge modes too outside of the story. The characters are witty, fun, have a lot of comedy, and are well scripted. The animation and art style is great, reminding me of a 2D cell shading or comic-book look almost. The gameplay itself may look repetitive, but it's intense and fun. Co-Op makes things even better as you play with a friend to clear out waves of enemies. All of this for $8, what a steal!
